ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Essay structuring
Writing improved and better understood how to develop a literary argument.
I developed a love for poetry in this class because it was the first time I read a lot of poetry. I also became a better essay writer.
I honed my writing skills. Professor Alaimo gave me great feedback, and pushed me to think deeper and more critically.
Developed an ability to read and appreciate poetry and literature as well as develop sound arguments on various works, including improving writing style and technique
I recognized a distinct improvement in my writing style while taking this class. I felt more confident in my writing after each of the four essays we wrote.
How to analyze sources and structure a research paper

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Shorter readings

Strengths- 
1. Covers a wide range of material, from poetry and prose to more nonfiction analysis. 
2. Topic is extremely relevant to present day. 

Weaknesses 
1. We don't go into as much depth on individual authors or time periods because there is such a wide range of content.
Strength of the class was the frequent office hours and feedback. Opportunity to do multiple drafts also helped.

Strengths: Mr. Alaimo organized the course really well. He is passionate, which is a good thing. The course had some readings I really liked, too.
Weakness: I would have liked to discuss the origin/implications of the alleged political divide between country and city. We did this a little, but ended up discussing way more the different portrayals of country and city life.
I think this is a fantastic course overall. I might have liked it if we read less pieces, but went deeper in our analysis of all of them.

I don't think there were weaknesses in this course besides the occasional silence in the classroom either from a lack of reading across students due to a busy week or just general shyness from starting the discussion. The selection of works throughout the semester was so interesting to read and I love that we got to even watch a film and read a couple of books. The reading was super manageable thanks to Marcus changing around the works we were reading a couple of times and the essays we wrote each had rough drafts which allowed for ample time to apply feedback from Marcus or from classmates. Overall, a really great way to get introduced to writing at college, a great way to improve your writing, and a great English class to read, discuss, and enjoy literature!
My favorite course this year. Marcus Alaimo provided awesome feedback for each of my essays that I incorporated into the next assignment.
This course had great instructional material on how to write a research and analytical paper and was very helpful, the day to day assignments and readings became a little monotonous however

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I thought that the professor was excellent and the content was interesting. I appreciated all of the time that was put into more general writing advice, as well as opportunities for feedback. Overall it was an excellent course.
Yes, I would recommend this course, as I feel that my writing improved because of the class.

If you like to think/philosophize about life in the city and country and what those two things represent to us, then definitely take this course. 
If not, then don't.
Yes. Great way to improve as a writer, and critical thinker.

Definitely recommend, this class allows you to both engage with literature and hone in on argumentative essay writing and I think this would be a great class to take if you are interested in the topic and want to either improve your writing or continue to incorporate writing in your Yale semester; plus Marcus is a great teacher and is very thoughtful yet critical when hearing your thoughts and arguments about a work which makes for diverse class discussions and really productive office hour meetings.
Yes. Very helpful introduction to college essay writing, in an engaging seminar style.

Yes, if they are in need of an introduction to higher academic writing with a really great teacher. If they had a lot of practice with this in high school, I wouldn't say a student would get very much out of this course in terms of new writing skills, though the content was interesting.
Yes, it was helpful for writing papers, but make sure you're very interested in the country and the city before taking this class

extras.title: ENGL 115 02 - The Country and the City
